Feature Stub

Recent:

Day 10 - Trello's Board Backgrounds

100daysofgoodux100daysproject

What it is: When setting up a new Trello board, you can set a background for it. There’s also a little die that lets you randomize the board background.

Why it’s good: Trello walks a fine line as a brand. On the one hand, they’re playful, silly, and earnest. Their mascot is a Husky named Taco. C'mon. On the other hand, their service is used for everything from home organization (which fits the brand well) to critical business processes (in which the brand could feel pointless and frivolous.) Consequentially, they take a light touch with the sillyness in the actual interface.

Here though, the board backround really isn’t that consequential, and they get that. The randomization function is handled quietly and simply, and with a little zest of fun. It’s a great example of an easter egg that enhances functionality without hindering expert workflows.

Day 9 - Rosenfelds Book's Chapters

100daysofgoodux100daysproject

What it is: At the beginning of each chapter, there’s a breakdown of important subheads, a small line diagram, and a full color spread.

Why it’s good: The books that Rosenfeld publishes walk a fine line between reference manual and professional development. These chapter leadins are so successful because they so accurately consider why the consumer is reading this book. The full color spread makes it easy to find these pages as you flip through the book. Detailed headings give an overview of the chapter contents, as well as their locations. My favorite bit is the line graph though, which gives you an example of the relative length of this chapter to the entire book. It’s similar to a Kindle saying “3 hours left in this book,” but more subtle and beautiful.

Day 8 - Android Lollipop's Camera

100daysofgoodux100daysproject

What it is: When recording a video with the standard camera in Android Lollipop, holding the phone in portrait mode gives a small icon that prompts you to rotate the phone.

Why it’s good: I’m not the type of person to describe vertical video as a disease of our time, but I’m not exactly the biggest fan of it. In this case, this little reminder seems like a great solution. It doesn’t get in the way, it doesn’t prevent you from recording, and it disappears as soon as you begin recording.

The small reminder is subtle and useful, so hopefully your video isn’t ruthlessly letterboxed on Youtube. Slick.

Day 7 - Toggl's Browser Extension

100daysofgoodux100daysproject

What it is: Toggl is a simple, web based, time tracking app. They make a browser extension that places a small button in a variety of different web apps like Trello, Jira, and Gmail. Clicking the button pulls the relevant text from whatever the button is near, and starts a time entry for it.

Why it’s good: There are so many products available. There have been a wave of recent businesses that have made product integrations a central part of their strategy, like Slack or Stripe. Toggl has API integration as well, but it also has this lighter weight browser extension.

The beauty of this extension is that it doesn’t overcomplicate the idea behind timetracking. It gets that you are just trying to start an entry, lets you pick a few options, and then gets out of the way. It also tracks state in both the button and on the favicon, showing me that everything worked correctly. It’s quiet but efficient.

Day 6 - YNAB's Entry Screen

100daysofgoodux100daysproject

What it is: YNAB is a budgeting app (Short for You Need a Budget (You probably do)). It is a powerful example of a UI being shaped by underlying philosophy. Back to the point - When you are entering income, if you indicate something is income and then enter the dollars in as an outflow, it stops you with a modal window.

Why it’s good: Modal windows are awful. This is especially true in an interface like this, where I’m using all keyboard entry and have to find my mouse.

This modal is necessary though, and it is a gold standard for best practices. It appears at a reasonable time, after I’ve finished typing and hit enter or clicked save. It has very short, scannable copy that includes bold text to help me figure out the issue. It uses semantically accurate copy on the buttons, indicating what each does. It even has a somewhat self deprecating header “Hey user, I’m being rude, just let me check this really quick.”

It is rude, but it’s saved me more than one headache as I speed through entering transactions and so I’m grateful for it.
